I'm a liberal_arts major with a bent towards history. I started as an economics major, but my school[.] program is largely quantitative and I was interested in more of the "why?" and "how?" behind economics. I switched out of that to my current major and have felt very fulfilled with what I learn. I'm able to bend my classes and assignments to a more "market history" curriculum. It[.] worked out pretty great for me. I spent one class studying the economics of the Weimar Republic, another on the effects of increased regulation under Wilson (hint: anyone who[.] studied this would have been able to predict the Feds action during the 08' crisis), and others. 

I've found what I do in school has lent to a more long_term view of the markets and business cycles than what my peers in the business school have. 

When I actually became interested in investing and fundamental analysis I taught myself accounting & financial modeling and didn't find it terribly difficult. I still love learning new concepts, though. In particular I have been interested in forensic accounting techniques and ways to uncover fraud/aggressive accounting in company financials. 

I'm very involved with our business school though. I was the portfolio manager (now TA) of our student investment fund ($1. 5mn AUM) which is a class for credits and I'm involved in our investment club. In particular with the club I lead development seminars once a week for freshmen/sophomores who want to get involved in finance (banking, PE, HFs, etc).
